This,however, is almost surely not true.Johnson's [1939) analysis of the Roosevelt administration's gold policysuggests that to the extent that the Treasury was responding to the real.economy, it was trying to counteract the Depression through easy money, ratherthan trying to accommodate the recovery. That is, the administration was, ifanything, seeking to increase the money supply because output was low, notbecause output was high or growing. Johnson stresses that Roosevelt's desireto encourage a gold inflow was not based on a conventional view of themonetary transmission mechanism, but rather on the view that an increase inthe gold supply would directly raise prices and reflation would directlystimulate recovery [1939, pp.
